title: Rise time
text:
In <a href="electronics">electronics</a>, when describing a <a href="voltage">voltage</a> or <a href="current%20%28electricity%29">current</a> <a href="step%20function">step function</a>, rise time is the time taken by a <a href="Signal%20%28electrical%20engineering%29">signal</a> to change from a specified low value to a specified high value. These values may be expressed as <a href="ratio">ratio</a>s or, equivalently, as <a href="percentage">percentage</a>s with respect to a given reference value. In <a href="analog%20electronics">analog electronics</a> and <a href="digital%20electronics">digital electronics</a>, these percentages are commonly the 10% and 90% (or equivalently and ) of the output step height: however, other values are commonly used. For applications in control theory, according to , rise time is defined as "the time required for the response to rise from to of its final value"", with 0% to 100% rise time common for <a href="underdamped">underdamped</a> second order systems, 5% to 95% for <a href="critically%20damped">critically damped</a> and 10% to 90% for <a href="overdamped">overdamped</a> ones. According to , the term "rise time" applies to either positive or negative <a href="step%20response">step response</a>, even if a displayed negative excursion is popularly termed <a href="fall%20time">fall time</a>.
Overview.
Rise time is an analog parameter of fundamental importance in <a href="electronics">high speed electronics</a>, since it is a measure of the ability of a circuit to respond to fast input signals. There have been many efforts to reduce the rise times of circuits, generators, and data measuring and transmission equipment. These reductions tend to stem from research on faster <a href="electronic%20device">electron devices</a> and from techniques of reduction in stray circuit parameters (mainly capacitances and inductances). For applications outside the realm of high speed <a href="electronics">electronics</a>, long (compared to the attainable state of the art) rise times are sometimes desirable: examples are the <a href="Dimmer">dimming</a> of a light, where a longer rise-time results, amongst other things, in a longer life for the bulb, or in the control of analog signals by digital ones by means of an <a href="analog%20switch">analog switch</a>, where a longer rise time means lower capacitive feedthrough, and thus lower coupling <a href="noise">noise</a> to the controlled analog signal lines.
Factors affecting rise time.
For a given system output, its rise time depend both on the rise time of input signal and on the characteristics of the <a href="system">system</a>.
For example, rise time values in a resistive circuit are primarily due to stray <a href="capacitance">capacitance</a> and <a href="inductance">inductance</a>. Since every <a href="electrical%20network">circuit</a> has not only <a href="electrical%20resistance">resistance</a>, but also <a href="capacitance">capacitance</a> and <a href="inductance">inductance</a>, a delay in voltage and/or current at the load is apparent until the <a href="Steady%20state%20theory">steady state</a> is reached. Other definitions of rise time, apart from the one given by the <a href="%23">Federal Standard 1037C (1997</a>, p. R-22) and its slight generalization given by , are occasionally used: these alternative definitions differ from the standard not only for the reference levels considered. For example, the time interval graphically corresponding to the intercept points of the tangent drawn through the 50% point of the step function response is occasionally used.
